item.description:
In Canaille, each player takes the role of a fisherman to takes part of fishing contest and must compose short plays ending in a point by using the action cards.

But the cat Canaille goes around and try to steal the fruits of your fishing. Be smart and send Canaille at your opponents!

In his turn player lines up in front of him 1-5 cards in
a specific order as his fishing luck and takes actions accordingly: drawing cards trying to catch fish, exchanging cards or sending the cat to steal fish from other players.

Player with the most fish at the end of the game is the winner.

Poker meets bingo.
The goal of the game is to accumulate a maximum amount of coins into 3 parts, by collecting over the cards announced the best combinations.

The game is divided into three parts:
1) Pre flop is the phase of play before seeing cards.
2) Turn is the second time to bet after seeing the cards.
3) River is the last to bet before unveiling his game

Players bet for the cards to get better combinations for their boards.

Player who accumulated the most chips at the end of three parts is the winner.

The first player takes as many tiles he thinks he can remember and forms face-down tile-row on the table.
The next player can either add a tile to the row to be the first player or place it behind the row. All players do the same.

The player who leads the row must state the colors of the tiles one by one. If successful, it gets rid of his generous balls of wool by distributing to each opponent. If he's not successful, the other shepherds give him a free ball of wool. And it was the turn of the second player on the row to state the colors.

The first player to get rid of his balls of wool wins the game.

An observation, memory and dexterity game for 2-4 little detectives.
Inside the box there is a castle with ghosts, and a tower in the middle. The ghosts are encrypted cards, hidden in the castle’s walls and players can see them thanks to a special red lens.
Inside the tower there are 4 bags, one for each player.

Players have to find the ghosts and try to drop them from the tower inside their bags.
During the game, each player has a target ghost.
During his round, the player moves his detective in the room he wants. He looks with the special lens the ghosts in the room.
After 10 seconds, the player can indicate one ghost:
- if it’s the same ghost of his target, he takes 3 little ghosts (each ghost is a small ball). He tries to put them in his bag from the tower. The player draws a new target ghost.
- otherwise, if it same ghost of another player, this player will drop 3 little ghosts. This player draws a new target ghost.
- if nobody has the ghost, the other players will drop 1 little ghost.
If the player thinks that his ghost isn't in the room, he doesn't choose any card: nothing appends.

When targets or little ghosts finished, the game ends.
Players remove the castle and look at the bags: the player with more little ghosts wins.

A dexterity game for 2-4 players, with a tree and 30 cubes.
Roll 2 dice, then use a cube to lengthen your giraffe's neck, according to the colour and the special action of the 2 dice.
Special actions:
- put the neck on the top of your giraffe;
- put the neck on the bottom of your giraffe;
- put the neck on the top of your giraffe, without using the thumb;
- lift the giraffe over the table, put the neck on the top;
- steal the neck from an opponent (you will take the coloured neck and the other necks over it).
The player who reaches the leaf on the tree wins.

Turniej ZÅ‚otoroÅ¼ca is a easy to learn polish card game for 2-3 players, in which everyone tries to get the most victory points by defeating opponents in duels (your card have to got more points of might, strenght, wisdom or beauty - depending on kind of duel). The main mechanic is very similar to card game "War", but is less random because players can choose which card play (from 4 available).

Game consist:
- 60 cards
- rulebook

Cardgame consisting of 69 playing cards and 3 instruction cards (English & Dutch), developed for dart players by (the dart brand) Bull's.

Rules include a introduction and full game, and offers variants for both.

All 62 dart board scoring areas are represented by individual cards, thus creating 3 suits: singles doubles and trebles.

On a player's turn, a player select an open or blind card, and either returns a card, or plays a shot. The amount on the card is subtracted from the players score, which (by agreement) can be 101, 201, or 301. To win a player had to hit exactly 0 with the last shot, AND the last card played should be a 'double'.

In the more advanced game the player is allowed to open as many 'pile' as he likes, but scores negative points for unfinished piles.

Il Vecchio is set in the 15th century, when Cosimo de Medici – also called "Il Vecchio" ("the Elder) – and his family ruled over Tuscany and its capital Florence. The players represent the heads of Florentine families trying to rise their families to power. To achieve this, they send out their family members to locations in Tuscany to perform various tasks, specifically to recruit followers (knights, assassins, abbots) and collect money as both are needed to take control of provinces in neighboring regions; controlled provinces provide power and a bonus action. Another task is to gain the favor of the squirearchy as these favors are indispensable when it comes to getting an official position in Florence, e.g., a seat on the town council to enhance actions in Tuscany, or a noble rank to gain power at the end of the game.

To complete these tasks, however, a proper middleman must be present at a location, and as these middlemen travel a lot, they are rarely met. That's why it is so important to have one's family members in the right place at the right time – to save on time and money while achieving one's goals.

At the beginning of the game, each player has four family members in Tuscany. Players take turns performing exactly one action. Before his action, a player may pay money to move one of his own family members to another location. The available actions are to:


 Take a location-specific action in Tuscany. This requires both a middleman and one of your own standing (active) family members at that location. After the action, this family member is laid down (inactive).
 Travel to another region and take over a province, which costs both followers and money.
 Travel to Florence where you'll spend scrolls (and possibly money) to claim a city council or nobility tile.
 Introduce a new family member to the board.
 Raise all lying family members on the board.


The game ends when the "Power of the Medici" has faded, as indicated by a diminishing pile of crest tiles. Certain actions require you to remove such a tile, and the game ends when they're all gone. Players then sum their power points – earned for gained tiles and majorities in the regions and Florence – for a final scoring, and the player with the most power wins.

item.description:
Each player places snake pieces on the board, either continuing an existing snake, or ending one to start another. The snakes are scored once there are two ends, and the player with the majority of the pieces in that chain scores the points.

The board has 10 snakes on it, and each snake's eye holds a special token (hole, twist, cross). These are randomly chosen and placed by all players when starting the game. A hole is impassable, but a twist allows a player to twist any snake piece on the board. This can change things considerably! The cross is an intersection that ends all snakes that touch it.

Twisted Tails was created by Kevin Kulp and J. Tagmire at the 2012 Global Game Jam. This year's theme was Ouroboros.

Game description from the publisher:

Just as the Four in a Square suggests, you want to be the first player to form a square with four balls of your color.

On a turn, you place a ball of your color in an empty spot, then slide a board tile to try to get four of your color in a square. That's it!

Jinx is a new Game in the Dixit family. Unlike the original game, the drawings are not realistic illustrations depicting scenes but more abstract images.
During the game, 9 cards are placed face-up in a 3x3 square. The active player draws a locator map that will show them which of the nine cards they will play with. This location is kept secret.

The player speaks, sings, or acts out something relating to this card (just as in "Dixit"). 
The other players go around and point to the card they think is correct. Only one player can point to each card. Once a player has chosen the right card, the turn stops. The player who finds the right card keeps it. Each card counts as a victory point. Players who were wrong give their cards to the active player. But if neither player gets the right card, the active player must return a previously won card.

item.description:
Objective:
be the first to move all of your five meeples forming a row within one of those black lines with white dots
 - moving by turn -
players place their meeples into coloured start positions (spread all over the board)
players move their meeples to adjacent junctions
 - allowed only if space isn't already occupied
try to find shortest way to rejoin your meeples - or block others if they could be faster than you
remarks:
produced before WWII

Wizard’s Museum is a quick-to-play game of tile placement and set collecting for two to five players. During the course of a game, players take on the role of wizards in competition with one another as they try to build the best and most well-ordered museum of magical artifacts, all while sabotaging the efforts of their friends and colleagues.

Players manage a hand of tiles, drawing and playing a single tile each turn across their own and their opponents collections. Each tile features a magical artifact in its center and four magical gates on its edges. Tiles are played to match the edges of their neighbors, but points are won and lost by matching -- or failing to match -- artifacts. Will you add to your museum or disrupt your neighbors?

item.description:
Map It! U.S. Edition uses the same game play as the German-language 'Ausgerechnet!' series of games: Players deal three piles of 15 location cards from a deck of roughly 200 cards (naming cities and landmarks in the U.S. for this edition). They take one deck of 15 cards and put one location card on the direction board, pointing north, south, east and west.

On a turn, a player draws a location card – keeping the latitude and longitude on the back of the card secret from all players – then places the card next to the direction board, indicating how they think this location relates to the starting one. Is Honolulu west of San Francisco? Why sure, so place it by the west arrow. Location cards can be placed between cards already on the board.

After each location card is placed, any player can challenge the positioning of that card. That player reveals the back of the most recently placed card as well as one adjacent card. If the challenge was correct – and the card placed wrongly – the challenger wins a point chip from the placer and the card is removed; otherwise the challenger hands over a chip to that person.

After 15 cards are placed, there is an interim scoring in which all players secretly guess how many cards have been placed correctly. Guess correctly, and you score two chips; if no one is spot on, the closest guesser wins a chip.

After three rounds and the final interim scoring, the player with the most chips wins.

Into the Fray is a print and play skirmish level fantasy war-game from Moss Games.

Into the Fray allows each player to take control of one of the factions of the Hundred Worlds. Each group attempting to uncover the secrets of the lost world of Gateway and crushing anyone who stands in their way.

Designed so that each player will field between 15 and 20 figures in a standard battle, a game of Into the Fray (ITF) will last about 2 hours with experienced players. The game includes rules for the standard fare like movement, combat and morale, and also includes a system for magic and special abilities that will keep things interesting, even for veteran players.

Available only in an electronic format, ITF is a print and play game. It keeps the initial cost down and allows you to make as many or as few miniatures as you need to form your army. With a few supplies (cardstock and glue sticks) and a few hobby tools (a hobby knife and a straightedge), you can build all of the cards, miniatures, counters and templates you need. Add in a handful of six siders and a tape measure and you will be ready to get Into the Fray!!

"Chameleon - the game where you can run and you CAN hide!

Chameleon is a new and exciting board game that is a combination of Chess, Draughts, Chinese Checkers and Backgammon. It is a game of tactics, cunning and ambush.

Plan your attack, secure your defence, strike when ready.

Chameleon is played on 6 colour game board and comes with 12 pegs, 2 'chameleon' die, a rules booklet and a strategy brochure. Each player (either black or white) plays with 6 pegs that are red, yellow, green, blue, orange and purple.

The aim of the game is to be the first player to move all six tokens from your 'starting grid' into your 'home base' whilst trying to stop (or zap!) your opponent from doing the same. If you're on your own colour you are a chameleon and can't be seen. If you're off your colour you'd better watch out!"

item.description:
The peaks of Snowdonia rise before you, encased in mist, their summits barely visible. The highest is Snowdon (Wyddfa) herself at 1,085 metres. The year is 1894, and the Snowdon Mountain Tramroad and Hotels Company Limited has been formed to build a branch line from Llanberis to the summit. You can scarcely believe it's possible!

In Snowdonia players represent work gangs providing labour for the construction of the Snowdon Mountain Railway. Unlike other train games you will have to excavate your way up a mountain side, as well as make and lay the track, construct viaducts and stations. All this in competition with the weather of the Welsh mountains (and the game itself)!

You may be assisted by a train (though that's not always best) and you'll be able to collect essential materials from the Stock Yard. You will obtain special work contracts that give you bonuses.

Can you contribute more than the other players to the magnificence of the Snowdon Mountain Railway?

Snowdonia: The North Pole & The Great Bridge Scrapyard Promo Tile

item.description:
Tâb is a traditional Egyptian abstract game played in a number of Arabic-speaking countries. It is classified by the game historian R. C. Bell as a "running fight" game and by the game historian David Parlett as a "linear war" game. Games in these categories are relatively rare (Tablan, Puluc, and Daldos being virtually the only other known examples).

The game is played on a board with 4 rows and anywhere from 7 to 15 columns. One player fills the bottom row with playing pieces; the other player fills the top row with his or her pieces. Four casting sticks are used to randomly generate moves for the pieces. The two center rows of the board are treated as a looping track along which pieces move linearly in a counter-clockwise direction once leaving their home row. It is primarily on these two central rows that the battles take place, with a piece capturing an opponent piece by landing on its square. A few special movement rules add complexity and strategy to the game. A player wins by capturing all of the opponent's pieces.

There is some speculation among game historians that Tâb may be a descendent of the ancient Egyptian game of Senet (similarities include linear movement and the use of casting sticks).

Objective: be the first crossing finish line (110)
 - moving by turn -
simple roll & move game
blue fields push you forward, red fields backwards or stop you/ throw you out
remarks:
published early 1930's

The goal of the game is to reach the dragon of his opponent with his weapons, or eliminate it directly through the Fireball.
Each player takes a dragon, two clubs, two axes, two swords and a ball of fire.
Each dragon launches 2 to 3 meters. Then, each player throws in turn role of a weapon to touch the dragon of his opponent.
A club that hits the dragon of his opponent scores 3 points. a
axe scores 2 points and sword.scores 1 point.
The Fireball attack happens with closed eyes. If it touches the opponent's dragon or one of his weapons opponent is eliminated.

When two players have played all their cards, they count the number of points. Player who wins the three rounds is the winner.

The one of Japanese collectible card game that uses the Japanese anime art style. This game's art and theme is base on famous Japanese visual novels (PC games).

The main concept of the game is letting the Character cards join the battle and deal damage to the opponent's Character cards. Knock down 3 of them or an Ace Character card to win the game.

The card types in this game are
Character card, Event card, Item card, Battle card and EX skill card.

Deck construction has 3 parts: Main deck, EX skill deck and an Ace character card. Each player must have at least 60 cards in main deck and a Character card (total 61 cards). Optional, each player may have up to 3 EX skill cards for EX skill deck.

Unlike Magic: The Gathering, the Creature Cards in Magic: The Gathering have 2 values; Power value and Toughness value for attacking and defensing in the game. But in this game's Character cards have 5 values. Each value will be determine which is the Attacking Value or Defense Value by the Battle Cards. 5 Value are Force, Agility, Intelligence, Skill and Tranquility (This is unofficial translated.)
Example, one of Battle card determines Force for attacking and Agility for defensing. In that battle, Force become attacking value (power) and Agility becomes defensing value (toughness).

The huge amount of tokens are necessary to play this game for counting a damage in each Character card.

At last, there's a fun new way to avoid the dreaded "awkward silence" when dating someone new! Introducing ACQUAINT™ - the revolutionary "real deal" card game that helps first-, second-, or even third-time daters get better acquainted. It was designed not only to create conversation and calm nerves, but to also help daters better determine each other's "keeper" potentials; needless to say, finding out early on whether or not they are truly compatible may prove to be a time-saving, preventative measure of future heartache.

This highly interactive card game includes questions, tasks, lessons and more! It encourages 'authentic' conversation through the sharing of thoughts, experiences, feelings and values. Questions range from light-hearted topics to semi-personal and serious, and fun "off-the-wall" topics are included throughout.

OBJECT: Collect as many Rose Cards in your hand as you can by discarding as many other cards as possible. Players perform any task(s) listed on the discarded card on each turn. There are a total of 9 Rose Cards, and the player with the most in their hand at the end wins. The main point of the game, however, is for the players to get to know one another better.

CARDS: Includes 52 cards total 

 9 ROSE CARDS
 20 'REAL DEAL' QUESTION CARDS 
 4 FILL-IN-THE-BLANK CARDS
 6 DISCUSSION CARDS
 5 SCALE ("What # Are You?") CARDS
 6 MISCELLANEOUS CARDS ('Listening Check' Card, 'Deception Destroyer' Card 'Share' Card, 'Flirt' Card, 'Deal Breaker' Card, & 'Compromise' Card) 
 2 PROTECTION CARDS




START: SHUFFLE CARDS WELL before starting (keeping all the cards facing the same direction). Choose which player will go first. Players must also choose in advance the level of play preferred for the 'REAL DEAL' Questions from the three levels listed below.

REAL DEAL QUESTION CARD LEVELS: 

 LEVEL 1 ('a' questions) - Simple, light-hearted questions to learn a little about your date - questions that are generally easy to answer and don't take that much thought
 LEVEL 2 ('b' questions) - Moderate get-to-know-your-date questions - questions that get a little more serious, where people can reveal a bit more about themselves
 LEVEL 3 ('c' questions) - Deep questions designed to create a bonding emotional connection, or, to better spot potential 'RED FLAGS' in advance--ideal for 'bold' daters. Keep in mind DISHONESTY CAN DESTROY EVEN THE BEST OF RELATIONSHIPS! PLAY AT YOUR OWN RISK! Warning: Some questions may be considered to some as personally inappropriate for a new date, even though the questions are in good taste. (The reason someone may pass on a question need not be explained -- besides, a little mystery can often prove to be an effective strategy as well.)




PLAY: Each person is dealt 7 cards (one at a time) face down. The remaining cards are placed face down in a pile in the center of the table, forming the draw pile (or the Selection Pile). The first player (aka THE DISCARDER) takes a turn by drawing the top card from the Selection Pile followed by choosing a card to discard from his/her hand, reading it out loud first. Players then respond to any directions from the card accordingly. When finished, the DISCARDER places the card face up right alongside the Selection Pile, into what will be the Discard Pile (unless otherwise directed). Similarly, the other player then takes their turn, and so on.

SCORING: The game ends as soon as soon as the last card is picked up/discarded. The players then count the number of Rose Cards in their hands, and the player with the most roses wins. (If both players end up without any roses, it's considered a tie game.).

Players mine a minerals from the planets.
In each round, the player must decide which two characters he activate in the order of their choice, to collect the finest collection of precious minerals at he end of the game to be the winner.

There are 4 crew members:

 Captain Brown: (may move his rocket on the planet of player choice)
 Professor Glumdensen (may transforms one precious stones to another) 
 Agent X331 (may take a ore card fror each player on the galaxy)
 Joe the miner (may draw 2 ore cards)

In Speedeebee!, players race to complete challenges presented to them while using – or not using! – the letters rolled on four dice.

Each round players are presented with a challenge on one of the fifty challenge cards; each card has three challenges, and the challenge to be used is determined by the color on the back of the challenge card previously won. Someone reads off the challenge – for example, name something taller than five feet starting with one of the rolled letters – then the player rolls the letter dice. Whoever calls dibs first and names something correctly wins the card; if a player makes a wrong guess, he's penalized one card that he claimed previously.

Whoever has the most cards after going through twenty challenge cards wins!

item.description:
Object of the game is to find the possible pairs of animals.

Depending on the number of players have 9 to 18 cards face down in front of each participant.
In his turn, a player can turn around:
- two cards in front of him
- one card in front of him and an other card in front of any opponent.

If the two cards are identical, each player can shout "Memo".
The player who shouts first gets the two cards as a reward.

In the event of a tie, the player closest to the active player wins the cards.

The first player who manages to have all the cards in front of him wins.

Each player receives six cards to start representing parts of the house they will have to go. These cards are visible to all.

Players roll the die and it shows some special displays or challenges when two players meet on the same part of the house.

Example of the challenges:
- One who whistles the strongest
- One who makes the biggest burp
etc. Who wins the challenges gives his card to opponent.

The winner is the one that gets rid of his cards first.

A French party game for younger audience in which players improvise themed performances in given characters.

Ih his turn player draws a card and try as much as possible to have success with the public with his task. He either must let the others guess a word through mime or speak text aloud, or improvise a sketch, or depict a scene with a partner.
Can be played in teams.

The most successful player/team is the winner.

name.value: Tier auf Tier: Jetzt geht's rund!
Animal upon Animal: Here we turn!
Dier op dier: naar de haaien!
Piramide di animali: A pieni giri!

item.description:
It's time to stack more animals, but as the title suggests, now you move around, too!

In Tier auf Tier: Jetzt geht's rund!, a crocodile is trying to drift peacefully across the ocean, but unfortunately for it, you and the other players each control a bunch of animals that want to go for an ocean cruise, so you'll take turns stacking animals on the crocodile's back. The ocean waves don't let the crocodile drift peacefully, however, and after each animal is placed, the player must rotate the crocodile on its turntable – taking care to watch out for the shark at the same time.

Whoever first stacks all of her animals on the crocodile's back wins!

The animals at the zoo are tired of constantly having to pose for photographs again and again, so they decide to steal a camera and take pictures of themselves to make the process more fun. Can you tell who has the camera?

In Kuck Ruck Zuck! you can't see which animals holds the camera – but you do have the snapshots as evidence of where the camera was, and by looking at the pictures you can tell which animals took which shot. But can you figure out which critter took which pic before anyone else?

Wally Walrus' island is a bright treasure, and only the shining light in the lighthouse keeps the water rats away from its shores. Wait, what's this? The light has gone out?! Now the rats have set sail for the island in their boat – they're not stupid water rats, mind you – and it's up to you and your fellow builders to ward them off.

To do this, players in Wasserratten in Sicht! will construct additional lighthouses brick by brick by rolling the right combinations of colors on the dice available to them. Can they get the lights to shine in time and keep the rats from overrunning the island and snacking on Wally's whiskers?

Wasserratten in Sicht! includes a competitive variant.

item.description: Act Too, a.k.a. Mimtoo, is a simple game of miming and gestures that is played in teams. One player on the active team draws both a character card and an action card, then silently acts out the card combination – for example, an electrician dancing the polka. This player's teammates have one minute to guess the answer, collecting a card if they do so. The team that collects the most cards wins!

This game is based on the film “Finding Nemo,” specifically the scene in which Dori and Nemo’s father find the goggles at the bottom of the sea. Players play as the two fish and need to get the goggles.

This is a print and play game. The pdf includes the following components:
-cards
-goggles token
-special dice
-board

Players will need to prepare the following component (not included in the pdf):
-a normal 6-sided dice

Players roll a special dice to determine one’s movement. When you reach an “Info” box, you roll the normal dice and it determines the place of the goggles.

The player who gets to the goggle space the fastest is the winner.

The ancient origins of a civilized sport. Play Test, Limited Over or Twenty20 versions of the game at its most hallowed amphitheater.
The Gentleman’s game of Cricket originated in England, is played on a circular arena, and since a Trilithon resembles an ancient giant set of cricket stumps, anthropologists have recently hypothesized that Stonehenge may actually have been built as an ancient cricket ground. One look at a photo of Dr. W. G. Grace should provide further proof of Druidic involvement in the sport.
This game is for the Stonehenge Game System

The Druid Council has become weakened through in-fighting and years of drought. The leader of each Druidic chapter races to seize control of the council and assume power as Chief Druid. Upon establishing command he unleashes a team of assassins to eliminate his political enemies, and become the unopposed Supreme Grand Chief Druid.

This game is based on the ancient African (Baggara Arabs of the Sudan) game of Li’b el Merafib or Hyena, which may have been based upon an unknown ancient Druidic game, which may have been based upon actual events at Stonehenge.

For the Stonehenge Game System
Players race around the board, the first to reach the council seizes power. They then unleash assassins to hunt down the other players. After all political rivals have been purged or exiled, the winner flaunts their status with a huge victory rally.

name.value: F-16 ファイティング・ファルコン

item.description:
F-16 Fighting Falcon is a tactical level air combat wargame in modern warfare. Players control the few jet fighters. The game performs in two steps of changes of flight status and actual move on the board. Flight status is represent five levels of attitude and pitch. It works to control easily the change of altitude and turning.

This game covers only air to air combat, and does not include ground attack. Victory conditions vary by scenarios. For example, shooting down enemy aircraft.

This game was designed for wargame beginners.

In this Swedish trivia game players take turns being the "Bankir". The "bankir" is selling question cards to the other players with three headlines. Then the "bankir" is drawing a letter and every player has two minutes to fins out a words that match the headlines on their card. If you finish your cards you can buy more from the bankir. If you answer correclty you get money from the bank and the one with the most money in the end wins.

item.description:
From the publisher:
In this hilarious family game, players are challenged to perform different kinds of tasks while other players bet whether or not they can succeed in them. If the others guess correctly, they receive the amount of game money they bet as a reward, whereas you get a reward if you perform the task without failing. Wanna Bet? is an excellent addition to all game nights. Its interactive nature and hilarious content make it an instant hit with both adults and children!

A old swedish card game that consist of 100 cards with birds that can be found in sweden. The goal of the game is to collect group of cards with birds related to each other. This is done by sending a card you do not want to the player next to you and at the same time you get one from the other opponent.

In the game there is also a map of 325 birds that is recommendet to be used in biologyclasses in school.

From the publisher:
Tangram is a classic seven-piece dissection puzzle from China. In Tangram Race, each player has a set of tangram pieces. Pick a task card randomly and try to form the shape shown in the card. The first player to do so gets the card, and the first player to collect five task cards, wins the game! 
With three difficulty levels, Tangram Race is suitable for both beginners and advanced players. The game includes 200 tasks and solutions.

ΤΑ ΜΑΓΙΚΑ ΠΕΤΡΑΔΙΑ (MAGIC GEMS) is an abstract board game that three players try to through pass 10 gems to the other side of the board by dice rolling. The player who first takes all his gems to the other side is the winner.

item.description:
Wolf im Schafspelz is a fast-paced dice game in which you must quickly evaluate the roll of the dice and toss the right card in the right box. The faster you are, the more points you score – assuming you're correct, of course.

In the basic game, each player holds a wool card and the two halves of the box are laid face-up on the table, one showing a sheep in the bottom and the other a wolf. Players roll five or seven animal dice, depending on the number of players, then they try to scan the dice quickly to see which animal group – the sheep or wolves – are in the majority so that they can through their wool card in that box. Players who do so score 0-3 chips, depending on the number of players and how quickly they threw in their card; anyone tossing in the wrong box loses one chip. The first player to collect ten chips wins.

In the advanced game, a spice/wool die is rolled with the animal dice, and players need to throw the appropriate card – spice or wool – into the appropriate box. In the elite game, a blue animal die comes into play. If the blue animal die is part of the sheep/wolf majority, then game play is identical to the advanced game for that round; if not, then players must throw the symbol not showing on the spice/wool die into the right box.

One final variant can be used with all three levels of play: When the sheep are in the majority, those who score in the round receive a sheep chip; when the wolves are ascendant, they receive a wolf chip. The winner is the first player to collect both five sheep chips and five wolf chips.

name.value: Freedom: Le Chemin de Fer Clandestin

item.description:
Early in the history of the United States, slavery was an institution that seemed unmovable but with efforts of men and women across the country, it was toppled. In Freedom: The Underground Railroad, players are working to build up the strength of the Abolitionist movement through the use of notable figures and pivotal events. By raising support for the cause and moving slaves to freedom in Canada, the minds of Americans can be changed and the institution of slavery can be brought down.

Freedom is a card-driven, cooperative game for one to four players in which the group is working for the abolitionist movement to help bring an end to slavery in the United States. The players use a combination of cards, which feature figures and events spanning from Early Independence until the Civil War, along with action tokens and the benefits of their role to impact the game.

Players need to strike the right balance between freeing slaves from plantations in the south and raising funds which are desperately needed to allow the group to continue their abolitionist activities as well as strengthen the cause.

The goal is not easy and in addition to people and events that can have a negative impact on the group's progress, there are also slave catchers roaming the board, reacting to the movements of the slaves on the board and hoping to catch the runaway slaves and send them back to the plantations.

Through careful planning and working together, the group might see an end to slavery in their time.

link.value: Freedom: The Underground Railroad – Promo Cards

item.description:
From publisher:

Aliens vs Boy Scouts (Prepared? Always be prepared!) is a dynamic game for a large group of friends. Two teams are at a standoff: the aliens steal the boy scouts during the “night” phase of the game, and the boy scouts vote to eliminate one player during each of the “day” phases in an attempt to neutralize the aliens. The game develops diplomatic skills as well as analytical and deductive thinking. Based on the widely known game Mafia, Aliens vs. Boy Scouts offers a different plot together with expanded gaming abilities. The game has a number of advantages over its free print-n-play prototype:

- originally illustrated cards 
- new gaming elements: “objects” and “events”
- a different environment: one without murder and criminal activity 
- other useful materials: a referee chart and voting tokens

Antartik is a game for two to five players aged 5 and up, who embody penguins facing each other in a diving contest. They jump from the ice shelf, in the middle of Antarctica. The penguins must perform the most impressive series of artistic figures while avoiding a disastrous belly flop, which never goes unnoticed by the well-skilled jury.

The game is made of 55 cards, numbered from 1 to 10. There is only one card marked 1, whereas there are two cards marked 2, three cards marked 3, etc., and ten cards marked 10. Some cards marked 8, 9, and 10 also feature a bonus symbol in the top left corner, representing a judge or a parachute.

Game flow
Each player takes turn trying to make up a series of figures during his dive. He can perform three kinds of actions until his turn ends:

 Either drawing a card and place it in the center of the table so as to complete his series of figures. If the player draws a card which number already appears on one of the cards of the series, he keeps the last card he drew and his turn ends. The next player will choose either to keep the current series, or to return the series’ cards to the bottom of the deck.
 Or stopping the current series and taking all the cards it is made of before a pair is formed. The player’s turn ends.
 Or discarding a card with a "Judge" symbol to examine the top three cards in the deck and rearrange them in the order of his choice.




Before performing any of these three actions, the active player must wait for each of his opponents to:

 Either raise his hand in agreement.
 Or place (once per player during a series of figures) one of his cards in front of the active player’s series so as to confront him, and dare him to perform another figure. If the active player refuses the challenge or accepts it and loses, his turn ends and the player who dared him takes his card back and turns it over; now the card is worth 3 stars. If the active player accepts the challenge and succeeds, he immediately takes the card that was bet, he puts it in his stock and his turn goes on.




At any time, a player can turn over a card won during a successful challenge (i.e., a face down card) and draw the card at the bottom of the deck.

End of game
The game ends when the last card of the deck is drawn. The cards face up are worth one or two stars whereas the cards face down (from a successful bet) are worth three stars. The player with most stars wins the game and the title of "Antarctic Champion Diver".

Dégage is a semi-cooperative card game that takes on the theme of the Tunisian Jasmine Revolution (or more aptly named The Revolution for Dignity by the Tunisians. The goal is for the players to successfully eliminate the Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali and his clique mafia. The game revolves around these seven Zaba members; each have a specific power related to their personality that benefits them, but not those in the general population. These are known as character "defects" in the game. These "defects" are represented by various icons on the cards and indicate what "pressue" can be used to "eliminate" the character. Once players line up enough cards with the matching icons for a character, the character is removed. The person who dethrones the seventh character is the winner. If the 7 characters are not removed before the end of the game, all players have lost.

The goal of the game is to invent explanations to solve different puzzles and problems.

For example, if you read the riddle "Louis XIV was thrown from the roof of the castle and is not dead," you can explain that the castle was made of sand, there was a pool in the courtyard that Louis XIV fell into but it really hurts ... or that Louis XIV was actually the name of the big cat of Mary Pauline and he even landed back on its feet!

There are 4 rules for explaining:
- you create your own rules.
- You guess the explanation given by one player.
- The explanation must include a word that has nothing to do with the riddle.
- You have 1 minute to develop the story of opponent's explanation.

Every time you manage explain the enigma, you keep the card as a point.
At the end of the game the player with the most cards/points is the winner.

item.description:
Gitterrätsel! Junior is the kid's version of GitterrÃ¤tsel!.

Rotating the game board reveals a sequence of images, a word or an image in an open field of the board edge is visible. Whoever first discovers the corect sequence of pictures and letters on the board is the winner. Opponents compete to discover the hidden word first corresponding to the picture and mark it with tiles. However, if another player finds a word that is marked by another opponent's tiles than that opponent looses the word. Whoever has the most at the end pieces on the game board wins! This game promotes playful speed and concentration.

Time No Time Junior is the children's version of Time No Time.

Game play: Start the timer, draw a card, perform an task (see below), pass the cards to the next player. However, the timer is random and if the task is interrupted by the alarm, then that player gets a penalty chip. The player with the most penalty chips at the end loses the game.

The Junior version of the game includes colored wooden blocks. Players just arrange these blocks in various shapes and color combinations according to the cards.
A collectable version of the classic game Monopoly. This edition comes in the form of a die-cast semi-tractor trailer truck. The trailer opens to reveal a miniature version of the standard game.

name.value: Das kleine Ich bin ich: Würfelwettlauf

item.description:
The classic children's story Das kleine Ich bin ich tells the story of a little animal that looks similar to many other animals – yet because it's not identical to any of them, it questions its origins and place in the cosmos until it comes to the realization that "I'm not just anyone – I AM ME!"

In Das kleine Ich bin ich: Würfelwettlauf, kids relive the exciting journey of this little animal discovering itself. Turn by turn, players have up to three rolls of the dice to determine where their character moves on the path and which animals they have showing on the dice. If a player moves his token onto an animal space (frog, horse, hippo, dog) matching a rolled die and the player has not yet added all of those matching animal parts to his critter, he adds one piece jigsaw-style. The first player to complete his animal wins.

In his turn player draws a card and announce the title and artist of song. Players then bet on your success in the interpretation of the work. Finally, you push your bellowing, and each win or lose the bet.

A game for couples to find out what irritates them in their partners and what they really love about them. The game board is divided into to two parts, the first part of the board is about the things you hate and as you go on, you'll get to the side of the board that's about the things you love about your partner.

The game includes three different categories. The annoying things in your partner, the really irritating things in your partner and the things you love in your partner. In the first three categories, the pair draws three cards and then both of them arrange the cards in order of most annoying or most lovable by writing them up on paper. The pairs take turns on whose point of view the cards are arranged. If they get the most annoying/lovable thing right, they'll move 2 steps, if they'll get all right, they'll move 3 steps.

Also included is "What would you do category?" that challenges the partners to think how they or their partner would act in different specific situations, for example, how would you act if your mother-in-law would pay you a visit?

The pair that crosses the finish line first wins!

item.description:
Your goal is to be the first to have set up your herd of 10 cows, calves and bulls of the same color.
But beware! Your opponents are ruthless and will not hesitate to send you the worst nasties like drought, mad cow etc.

In his turn player play a card for his herd or nasty card for his opponent.

Player who set up his herd first avoiding the nasty cards is the winner.

The Drinking game version of Battleship! Secretly arrange your BattleShots™ ships on your shot board, placing them either horizontally or vertically. Each ship is composed of a designated number of shot glasses placed in a row. You should have three shot glasses for the battleship, two shot glasses for the destroyers, and one shot glass for your submarine.

Spodd is a two player game with a twist for the Shibumi game system.

Equipment: the 4x4 Shibumi board, balls in two colors. The board is rotated 45 degrees to have clearly seven columns with varying number of balls (1-3-5-7-5-3-1 on the surface of the Shibumi pyramid).

Rules: the board starts with two red balls placed in the left and right corner holes. Two players, White and Black, take turns placing one ball of each color adjacent to each other. The balls can be placed on board holes or on top of 2x2 platforms of existing balls. You can place a ball on a hole and the other on a platform, as long as they touch each other.

Aim: without the left and right corner holes there are five columns with an odd number of balls on the pyramid surface (3-5-7-5-3). When the pyramid is complete, the player with the most visible balls in a column wins that column. The winner is the player who has won at least 3 columns.

Variant for expert players: players score one point when they have conquered a column composed by three balls, two points for a five balls column and three points for the seven balls column. The winner is the player with the highest score.

Note: the game has an odd number of columns composed by an odd number of balls. Ties are not possible.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

The "It's all about grAtitude!" project began with an idea several years ago to teach, in a fun and entertaining way, age-old universal principles of prosperity and abundance that have been taught in every major spiritual and cultural tradition. Those principles are known today by names such as Law of Attraction, Law of Allowing, Law of Gratitude, etc.

The idea, conceived by Theuns Serfontein in South Africa, was to use a board and card game (played much like a cross between Monopoly and Trivial Pursuit) to teach and promote these principles. In 2010 the Law of Attraction worked to put Theuns together with Steve Vernon (a graphic and web designer in the United States) through an online marketing company in which they both were involved and, thanks to Skype, they became not only business partners, but very close friends. A few months later, Theuns asked Steve to partner with him in his dream of creating "grAtitude!"- the game (originally called "Bridge to Success").

The grAtitude! board game is played by tossing dice, moving around the "G"-shaped track, drawing cards from any of the four decks (depending on what space you land on), and following the instructions on the card within a certain time frame. You may, for example, have 30 seconds to name as many things as possible that start with the letter "D" that you're grateful for and win 1000 grati for each thing you name, or you might be told the Universe just rewarded you with 5,000 grati because you wrote down three daily goals this morning, or you might be asked to complete a famous quote or answer a multiple choice question. With over 700 cards in the game, the possibilities are almost endless!

vintage roll dice and move game from 1941;
Players start at the coast of South America and "sails" west. 
The target is being the first to Sail to the Tonga Isles in one piece and find the great Pirate treasure, all the while avoiding bad weather, pirates, coral reefs and other dangers along the way.

There is only one rather swirly route that takes you across the pacific oceans over towards Australia and The target Tonga Isles (passing Islands and groups like Tahiti, Baker Island, Gilbert Isle, St Cruz & Fidji) and if you hit certain spots/numbers along the travel, actions are taken according to rulesheet.

Nit de Reis is a free web-published game offered by the radio station Catalunya Ràdio for the Epiphany feast of 2012 (the traditional day in Catalonia for giving Christmas presents to children, tha day of the three Magi).

It is a push-your-luck game with just six dice. In the dice there are three kinds of presents (low-valued, mid-valued and high-valued), the Magi and coal (the typical present that the Magi give to naught children). Each player can roll the dice up to five times and after each roll he can keep as many dice as he wants. You only get points for just one kind of present and only if the Magi are present. But beware! The first time coal appears, you lose one die, and the second time, you lose everything! So it's wise not to be too greedy! The three Magi don't like greedy children!

item.description:
In the card-driven board game Rialto, the goal is to earn the most victory points (VPs), which are awarded for a variety of things. The game board displays the six districts of Venice, and players earn VPs for placing council members into these, for building bridges and placing gondolas to connect the districts with one another, and for building advantageous buildings.

The game is played over six rounds, with each round consisting of three phases:

1. Acquire cards: Each player takes a set of cards.
2. Play cards: Players use cards to perform certain actions.
3. Activate buildings: Players may take advantage of their buildings and use their powers.

In phase 1, sets of eight cards are displayed (with six cards face-up and two face-down). Each player takes one set, then reduces his hand to seven cards. A card shows one of six specific characters (Architect, Merchant, etc.) or is a wild card.

Phase 2 consists of six sub-phases in a fixed order, one for each character. In each sub-phase, players choose whether or not to play one or more cards of that specific character. Each card allows them to perfom that character's action, for example:


 Take one piece of gold for each Merchant card you play.
 Place one council member into the current district for each Council card you play.
 Take a building with a value equal to or lower than the number of Architect cards played. The higher its value, the better its function.


Whoever plays the most cards in each such sub-phase receives a bonus of one free action of that type. In case of a tie, whoever is farthest along the "Doge" bar gets the bonus – and of course to advance on the Doge bar, players need to play Doge cards.

Finally, in phase 3, players may take advantage of their buildings. For each piece of gold paid, a player may use one of his building's ability.

Players collect VPs both during the game – from special buildings and by building bridges between districts – and at the end of it – for majorities of council members in each district. The value of each district evolves during the game: Each district is adjacent to four other ones, and at the end of the game, they will be connected either via bridges or gondolas. A bridge increases the value of the adjacent districts by 3-6 victory points, whereas a gondola increases this value by 1 point. The player with the most council members in a district earns VPs equal to the district's total value, the player with the secondmost council members earns half this value, and so on. While it's important to establish majorities in the districts, it's also crucial to control their values by cleverly placing those bridges and gondolas.

item.description:
Every cow needs a hay to eat and water to drink to produce You some milk.

In his turn player draws and places a card on the table horizontally as a cow or vertically as a resource and puts his token on that card if possible.

Game ends if deck is exhausted. Players check their cows how many hay and water they consume, how many milk they produce.
Each 1 hay + 1 water produce 1 unit of milk.
(f.e. if the cards around the cow are 2 units of hay, 4 units of water, but only 1 unit of milk - she produces only this one unit of milk)
The player with the most milk production is the winner.

Contents:

 48 cards
 4x4 tokens

Vanquish Sauron, destroy the Ring and save Middle Earth ... in twenty minutes!

Inspired by Knizia's best selling board game about Tolkien's opus, this condensed cooperative dicefest takes you and your band of hobbits in a quest to bring the Ring to Mount Doom.

In the game, players must help each other avoid and fight the dangers lurking in Middle Earth. Along the way, the players will pick up resources and gifts which they will record on their hobbit boards using 6-sided dice as counters. On a typical turn, a player will roll the event die to determine how a scenario advances --- will he pick up a resource or must he deal with a misfortune that would bring the Fellowship closer to Sauron's corrupting influence?

Game Components:

1 corruption tracking board
7 scenario boards
1 gandalf/elven gifts resource board
4 hobbit pawns
4 hobbit boards
6-sided dice for counters
1 Sauron pawn
1 ring token
4 resource dice (blue)
1 corruption die (white)
1 gray event die
1 red event die
30 cube markers
3 ‘sun’ life tokens
3 ‘heart’ life tokens
4 ‘ring’ life tokens

This free print and play game can only be distributed for non-commercial purposes.

A development of the philosophy that started with BoF I, it features an all new game engine based on real world theories and training doctrines proven in combat.

Elegant in design, the rules allow you to focus on commanding the men, leading the action, and coming to grips with the chaos and uncertainty of combat.

Baptism of Fire III has been designed with ease of play in mind allowing players to concentrate on decisions and action.

Baptism of Fire III represents an evolution of modern skirmish game thought. Imperfect information, uncertainties of command and a fluid, action driven activation sequence make for a hot and exciting table top game unlike any other.

Baptism of Fire III is our most unique and intense game to model skirmishes in WW2 and beyond. The focus is on Leadership, training and morale using a game engine like no other game. With pace and simultaneous interaction within a turn, players will find themselves engrossed in the unfolding action.

The unique game engine is the key to all this. Evolved from earlier TFP Games rules, the system uses a non-traditional card draw, the player with the initiative deciding from 2 to 5 cards, creating a pace of play and simultaneous resolution of both sides activations.

The rules also use a sliding dice scale to reflect relative difficulty to resolve tasks or functions. No adding modifiers to create impossibilities of failure or success. BoF3 instead changes the size of the die rolling against fixed numbers, a simpler and faster system.

Leaders form the centre of attention. They allow troops a greater degree of flexibility, and better Leaders will be able to motivate and lead their men more effectively. They do this through Command Points. Points may be spent to coax and motivate, direct actions more effectively, increase die sizes and more. Leaders with reserved Command Points may also be reactivated within the same turn, pushing the men hard as they read or anticipate the tactical situation better than inferior leaders.

Supplements allow you to play post-WW2 conflicts.

Cosmic Express is a quick-playing version of Fantasy Flight Games' extremely awesome Cosmic Encounter. It takes the elements of Cosmic Encounter that make it so fantastic (negotiating, backstabbing, variable alien powers, alliances) and tries to deliver it in a half hour playing time, and with far less components than the original.

The game replaces Encounter Cards with Encounter Dice, of which a player only has one at any given time. When having an Encounter, players can choose to Fight (hold the die in their fist) or Negotiate (keep their fist empty). The classic Prisoner's Dilemma outcomes apply, with mutually fighting players rolling their dice to determine a winner.

The game is completely free to print and play, and uses no artwork from Fantasy Flight Games. It is designed as a tribute to on of my favourite games of all time and as a thank-you to the BGG community, who has given me so much enjoyment and help in the last year.

Massilia the beautiful – its strategic location on the Mediterranean has made it an important trading port of the Roman Empire, bringing prosperity to the city. Its market has become one of the most popular on the coast, and merchants are fighting to be able to install their stalls. Competition is tough to make a fortune, especially since the customer is demanding. This requires having well-stocked stalls to attract the wealthy customers and increase its reputation. But be careful not to incur the wrath of the consul as this could cost you. However, you can always count on the gods and goddesses to give you a boost, with, of course, some offerings. And yes, everything is paid in this world ...

In Massilia, each player will be able to use different colored dice to perform actions. There are four different colors corresponding to four different actions. On his turn, a player can choose a die and perform the corresponding action: Buy goods at the port, move a client or the consul on the market, make offerings to divinities to recover bonuses (cards), and buy reputation. The value of the die shows the number of times that the action may be made. The goal is to obtain the highest reputation at the end of the day by setting up stalls on the market to sell goods at the best price that the player will have bought in port.

item.description:
Corporation$ is a modern economic game. Create ultimate wealth by building corporations that dominate their industries and test your investment skills by choosing which corporations to buy stock in. Expand your influence by merging corporations and starting new corporations in new industries. But be careful or you may over-extend and find yourself with no cash to keep your corporations running and then lose your influence!

Players start by choosing an industry to launch their corporation. Then they can buy stock in their corporation, increase the corporations market share, and even merge even merge with other corporations. The player has to decide which strategy will work to their benefit. Should they buy more stocks, increase their market share, or merge with other corporations.

During regular gameplay, players receive revenue from their corporations, pay expenses, buy and sell stocks, buy marketshare in the auction phase, or merge with other corporations.

The player with the most net worth at the end of the game wins!

With Corporation$ you must balance your ambitious goals of becoming the wealthiest billionaire while managing the growing needs of your corporations. Do it poorly and count yourself one of the many who have tried and failed. Do it well and you may become the greatest wealth-generating businessman and investor of all time! At least within the world of the game called Corporation$.

The idea of the game is to play ministers.
Every turn new minister becomes Prime Minister.

In each round players try to favor ministers to hope him raise the new prime minister and get something back to their pocket. 
Ministers can play a limited number of cards in each turn.

name.value: Line of Fire #13: Blood on the Alma

item.description: Blood on the Alma was released in Line of Fire Magazine # 13, "Blood on the Alma" is a 2-3 player game recreating the 1854 Battle of the Alma River at the brigade level. Each unit is represented by a stack of step counters that modifies attack strength. Each army plays differently-- the French have a more traditional sequence of play, their allies the British are activated by chit pull, and the outnumbered Russians must contend with morale checks while dealing with phases that are scattered throughout allied phases. The Russians have a terrain advantage which they historically squandered; the allies possessed a technological advantage in the Minie Rifle, but due to poor communication, it was not used by the British until late in the battle, when it turned the tide decisively. Combat is resolved by comparing modifiers to defense rolls, and the type of attacking unit determines the available outcomes. A number of factors, including victory for each side, are tied to and fluctuate with a single track, creating a sense of momentum and narrative.

item.description:
Pohjantähti is a Finnish literary game based on the Tällä pohjantähden alla novel by Väinö Linna. The game loosely follows the events of the book by having the players visit the places and people from the novel.

The game mechanic is simple, players roll the dice, advance and pick random cards from the deck to collect the property set required to purchase their own lands from the land owners. Random events from the cards and special tiles on the board mix the game up, but it is a race among the players.

item.description:
Requires: Standard 52 card poker deck with 2 jokers.

Theme
Grab your friends and go rafting down the river! Whirlpools will send you for a spin! Be the best rapid wrangler to win!

Gameplay
Setup
Shuffle the deck.

Each player draws 10 cards minus how many players there are. (ex. 4 players, draw 6 cards). The remaining cards are placed in the middle and are known as the Pile.

Turn Order
Turn Order
Start Oour Turn
a) Draw a card from the Pile…
b) Or, place 1 Jack, Queen, or King back into the bottom of the Pile to draw 2, 3, or 4 cards respectively.

Build a Raft
2) Place cards down on the table to start building rafts. You can swap cards in and out of your hand and onto rafts to improve the point totals of rafts.

End Your Turn
a) Play an Ace card…
b) Or, play a Joker card…
c) Or, End your turn.

What is a Raft
Building a Raft: Every raft that has 4 numerically consecutive cards and a face card on top is considered a complete raft. You may continue to improve complete rafts. Card suits do not matter.

Friendly Competition
Playing an Ace Card: This is called a Whirlpool. Say "Whirlpool", show the players your Ace, and put the ace into the deck. Every player places their hand into the deck. Shuffle the deck and draw the same number of cards you had before the Whirlpool (ex. if you put 6 cards into the deck because of the Whirlpool, draw 6 new cards).

Playing a Joker Card: This is called "Let's go down the river". Say "Let's go down the river", show the players your Joker, and put the joker at the bottom of the deck. Each player takes all of their incomplete rafts and puts them back into the deck. Shuffle the deck. Each player gathers all of their complete rafts and puts them aside to now be counted as points. These rafts are no longer in play.

Progress
Ending the Round: The round ends when a player is unable to draw cards from the Pile. The player with the highest point total wins that round.

Calculating Points: Points are calculated by adding up the number cards into a total. Then, add the face value cards into the total. Jacks are worth 1, Queens are 3, and Kings are 5 additional points.

Goal
Have the highest point total at the end of 3 rounds.

name.value: IOTA: The great big game in the teeny-weeny box

item.description:
IOTA is a card game in which players score points by adding cards to a grid. The deck consists of 64 regular cards and two wild cards; each of the 64 cards contains three properties – color, shape and number – with each property coming in four different types. The two wild cards are identical and can be played in place of any other specific single card. They can also be recycled by a player who can replace a wild card with a card that works in that position.

To set up the game, each player is dealt a hand of four cards and one card – the "starter" – is placed face-up on the table. The remaining cards for a draw deck.

On a turn you can add 1-4 cards connected to the grid established by the starter card. All cards must be placed in the same line. A line consists of 2, 3 or 4 cards in a row in which each individual property (color, shape and number) is either the same on each card or different on each card. You can also choose to pass and place some, none or all of your cards on the bottom of the draw pile and take new ones.

Maximum line length is four cards. Cards needn't be placed right next to each other as long as they are in the same line, and some spaces on the grid will be impossible to fill.

To score a turn, add up the face values of cards in lines either created or extended on that turn. If any of those cards are part of two lines, they're counted twice. If on a turn a player completes a line that is four cards long, all points for the entire turn are doubled. Double again for any additional four card lines created. Double again if you play all four cards on a single turn. A four-card line is called a lot.

The game ends when the draw pile is depleted and one player plays his last card. Double points for that turn. The game is over. High score wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The game consists of 31 tiles that will form the oval game board, 6 "memo" tiles with one color per side, 6 pawns and a die with six faces. When the game starts forming a path with 31 tiles oval course that will be different for each game. Tiles "memo", which have color front / back, are placed in the center of the table so as to show the four possible colors. Each player picks a color pawn.

In turn, the active player rolls the dice. If it's six, he misses a turn. If it's between 1 and 5, it has the choice between:
1: re-roll, but if it's 6 or the same number, it passes.
2: he moves his pawn to a number of dice equal to the tile.

The course ends with the tile "Peasant Confederation" and the first player to reach this tile is declared "Grand Winner".

In KEEP ROCK! all of the players are cavemen sitting around trying to be the player who collects the most points by hanging onto the unbroken ROCK, or by sticking the other players with the broken ROCK. At the end when the draw pile is gone and no more cards can be played, the player with the most points wins.

CONTENTS: 10 “TAKE ROCK” cards, 10 “ME BREAK ROCK” cards, 10 “GIVE ROCK” cards, 8 “NO BREAK ROCK” cards, 14 “KEEP ROCK!” cards, 6 SCORE ROCK cards, 1 ROCK accessory.

GAME PLAY: Take the SCORE ROCK cards and the ROCK out of the deck. Choose a dealer and deal 5 cards to each player. Now place the SCORE ROCK cards back into the deck, spaced at random intervals. The deck (as draw-pile) goes in the middle of the table w/ a discard pile next to it. The dealer starts with the ROCK (unbroken side-up) and goes first. Players each maintain a 5-card hand during play. On his turn a player must play 1 ACTION card and draw 1 card if possible; OR, he must pick one of the other players with whom to trade 2 cards in blind random fashion, and then he must pass his turn. When an ACTION card is played, the player whom it is aimed at may play the appropriate REACTION card if he can, then draw 1 card if possible. When a SCORE ROCK card is revealed, points are scored if possible (described below). Then the SCORE ROCK card is discarded and play continues. All cards that are played go into the discard pile face-up. When a player’s turn is finished, the next player clockwise takes his turn, and so on.

SCORING: 1 – When a SCORE ROCK card is revealed and a player has the unbroken ROCK, if possible he gets two cards from the discard pile as points; if only one is left, then just one. If no cards are in the discard pile, none are scored. 2 – When a SCORE ROCK card is revealed and a player has the broken ROCK, each of the other players takes one card from the discard pile in clock-wise order relative to the player with the broken ROCK. If the discard pile runs out it’s just “tough cave luck.” If no cards are in the discard pile, no points are scored. 3 – If a player has the unbroken ROCK at the end (when the draw pile is empty and no more cards can be played), that player collects 5 cards from the discard pile as points. 4 – If a player has the broken ROCK at the end, each of the other players collects 1 card from the discard pile as points. Players each count the points (cards) in their own collection pile and the player with the most wins the game!

item.description:
Zug um Zug: Deutschland is a stand-alone game in the Ticket to Ride series. Over the course of the game, players collect cards in order to then claim routes on the game board between two cities. Ideally the players create a network of routes that connect the cities showing on their secret ticket cards. Players score points both for claiming routes and for completing tickets, with incomplete tickets counting against a player's score. Whoever has the most points at the end of the game wins.

Zug um Zug: Deutschland, published solely for the German and Austrian market, consists of the same map as Ticket to Ride: MÃ¤rklin – with the game now set at the turn of the 20th century – but the game does not include the passenger mechanism from Märklin in which players scored additional points by moving passengers from city to city. In addition, the numbers of destination tickets and train cards differ slightly between the two games.

Part of Ticket to Ride series.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Heap is the madcap game of vehicular mayhem where the player who cobbles together the most outrageous vehicles wins!

Each player plays a gang of crazed goblins that have traveled across the post-apocalyptic wasteland in broken-down vehicles to converge on a gigantic heap of long-discarded scrap – perfect ingredients for demented automotive modification. In arena-style bouts, each gang selects its champion driver to storm the heap and duke it out for the best parts to upgrade their vehicles. Be first to trick out your vehicles and dominate the final pileup to rule the heap!

Interesting party game. 24 cards all depict pictures of a cat, in eight sets of three identical pictures. Having said that there are eight sets of three, the pictures are all fairly similar. So good observation will be needed.

Place all the cards around a room. Each participating guest must look at the pictures during the party and make their observations. The first one to hand in all eight 'versions' of the pictures, wins.

"Finding Words" is an educational game based on the movie "Finding Nemo". This game is all about coming up with words within 1 min to help Nemo.
 This game play itself is simple. You simply roll the dice and move forward the number of your dice.
 For you to win this game, you have to write as many words as you can. The word should somehow be related to the movie and start with the letter you stopped at.

A compilation of games includes rule sets for Checkers and Tic-Tac-Toe, plus several other games:

Meet in the Middle: One player uses a "mama" animal, the other uses a "baby" animal. They start at opposite ends of the board and alternate die rolls until the two animals meet.

Home Sweet Home: All of the animals are divided among the players. In turn, each player rolls the die and puts the number of animals rolled onto the game board. The winner is the person who gets all of their animals on first.

Suppertime!: Players get two animals and have to move them to the barn. On each turn, the player rolls one die and can split the movement between the two animals in any manner. Landing on a space occupied by another animal sends that animal back to the closest unoccupied colored space. The first player to get both of their animals to the barn wins.

Barnyard Chase: Each player selects an animal and places it on the opposite diagonal corners of the included checkerboard. In turn, players roll the die and move clockwise around the board. First player to pass the other wins.

There is a quote in one side of the card and three variants of people who could said that and answer and information about the quote in another side of the card.

In his turn player reads the quote and choose the variant. If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

"Brain" in English
There is a mathematical or linquistical exercise in one side of the card and answer in another side of the card.

In his turn player solves the exercise.
If it is correct he gets the card as a point.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

Game ends if the deck has exhausted and player with the most points is the winner.

Quizzard game for younger audiance where you not only have to be right, you have to be fast. The heart of the game is an electronic buzzer device that records who will answer the question first. Up to 6 players have this buzzer pad in front of them and the first one who hits the button gets to answer. However, you can lose points for incorrect answers so before you hit the button you'd better know the answer.
